edge: Andrew Stanton was involved in the development of Finding Nemo, as he wrote and directed the film.
Andrew Stanton directed and was involved in the development of Finding Nemo.
According to Andrew Stanton, his childhood interest in visiting the dentist's fish tank inspired him for Finding Nemo.
Andrew Stanton's family's visit to Six Flags Discovery Kingdom (formerly Marine World) in 1997 inspired him for Finding Nemo.
According to Andrew Stanton's interview with National Geographic magazine, the characters of Marlin and Nemo in Finding Nemo were inspired by a photograph of two clownfish peeking out of an anemone.
According to Andrew Stanton's interview with National Geographic magazine, the appeal of clownfish in Finding Nemo was inspired by their playful behavior of peeking out from anemones.
Stanton felt that a clownfish was the perfect type of fish for a character who has to go on a dangerous journey.
Beginning in early 1997, Stanton began writing the screenplay during the post-production of A Bug's Life.

Stanton originally planned to use flashbacks to reveal how Coral died, but realized that by the end of the film there would be nothing to reveal and decided to show how she died at the beginning of the movie.

In a scene that was eventually deleted, Gill told Nemo that he's from a place called Bad Luck Bay and that he has brothers and sisters to impress the young clownfish. However, the latter found out that he was lying by listening to a patient reading a children's storybook with exactly the same details.
Albert Brooks replaced William H. Macy as Marlin due to the character needing a lighter touch.
Director Stanton felt that Marlin needed a lighter touch and replaced William H. Macy with Albert Brooks.
Stanton was inspired to cast Ellen DeGeneres as Dory after watching her change the subject five times in an episode of her TV show.

The pelican character Gerald was originally a friend of Nigel, but the filmmakers could not find an appropriate scene for them that did not slow the pace of the picture, so Gerald's character was minimized.

Stanton himself provided the voice of Crush the sea turtle in the film's story reel and assumed they would find an actor later. When Stanton's performance became popular in test screenings, he decided to keep his performance in the film. He recorded all his dialogue while lying on a sofa in Unkrich's office.
Crush's son Squirt was voiced by Nicholas Bird, the young son of fellow Pixar director Brad Bird.
Megan Mullally was originally going to provide a voice in the film. The producers strongly encouraged her to use her Karen Walker voice for the role, but when she refused, she was dismissed.
Pixar's animators took a crash course in fish biology to ensure that the movements of the fish in the film were believable.
Pixar's animators took a crash course in oceanography to ensure that the movements of the fish in the film were believable.
Gini Cruz Santos integrated 'the fish movement' into the animation for Dory to make her look and feel like a real character.
Gini Cruz Santos integrated 'human movement' into the animation for Dory to make her look and feel like a real character.
Gini Cruz Santos integrated 'facial expressions' into the animation for Dory to make her look and feel like a real character.
The Great white shark, Bruce, is in reference to the animatronic shark used in the Universal film Jaws.
The music that plays for Darla is the theme music from the 1960 Alfred Hitchcock film, Psycho.
The shark they had used on set was nicknamed 'Bruce' after Bruce Raiman, who was Steven Spielberg's divorce lawyer.
The line 'Here's Brucey!' is a reference to the Jack Nicholson line from the 1980 horror film, The Shining.
The film was dedicated to Glenn McQueen, a Pixar animator who died of melanoma in October 2002.
Finding Nemo shares many plot elements with Pierrot the Clownfish, a children's book published in 2002, but allegedly conceived in 1995.
The author, Franck Le Calvez, sued Disney for infringement of his intellectual rights and to bar Finding Nemo merchandise in France. The judge ruled against him,

Disney Character Voices International's senior vice president Rick Dempsey, in collaboration with the Navajo Nation Museum, created a Navajo dubbing of the movie titled Nemo Há’dééstíí which was released in theaters March 18–24 of the same year.
The project was thought as a means to preserve Navajo language, teaching the language to kids through a Disney movie.

edge: Fall Out Boy's lead singer Patrick Stump performing it [in Navajo].
